title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Corinthians chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Corinthians Chapter 12.

questions.question: How many years ago did Paul say he knew a man in Christ who was caught up to the third heaven?
questions.correctAnswer: Above fourteen years ago
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 12:2 that he knew a man in Christ above fourteen years ago who was caught up to the third heaven.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 12:4, where was the man caught up to?
questions.correctAnswer: Paradise
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:4 says the man was caught up into paradise and heard unspeakable words.

questions.question: What did Paul say he will glory in, according to 2 Corinthians 12:5?
questions.correctAnswer: His infirmities
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:5, Paul says he will glory in his infirmities rather than in himself.

questions.question: What was given to Paul to keep him from being exalted above measure?
questions.correctAnswer: A thorn in the flesh
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:7 explains that Paul was given a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan, to keep him from being exalted above measure.

questions.question: How many times did Paul beseech the Lord to remove the thorn in the flesh?
questions.correctAnswer: Thrice
questions.explanation: Paul says in 2 Corinthians 12:8 that he besought the Lord three times that the thorn might depart from him.

questions.question: What did the Lord say to Paul about His grace in 2 Corinthians 12:9?
options: My grace is sufficient for thee
My power is weak in you
questions.correctAnswer: My grace is sufficient for thee
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:9, the Lord says His grace is sufficient for Paul and that His strength is made perfect in weakness.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 12:10, when is Paul strong?
questions.correctAnswer: When he is weak
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:10 states that Paul takes pleasure in weaknesses because when he is weak, then he is strong.

questions.question: What signs were wrought among the Corinthians to prove Paul's apostleship?
questions.correctAnswer: Signs, wonders, and mighty deeds
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:12 mentions that signs of an apostle were wrought among the Corinthians in signs, wonders, and mighty deeds.

questions.question: Who did Paul send along with Titus to the Corinthians?
questions.correctAnswer: A brother
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 12:18 that he sent Titus along with a brother to the Corinthians.

questions.question: What does Paul fear he will find among the Corinthians when he comes again?
options: Debates, envyings, wraths, strifes, backbitings, whisperings, swellings, tumults
questions.correctAnswer: Debates, envyings, wraths, strifes, backbitings, whisperings, swellings, tumults
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:20 lists the negative behaviors Paul fears he will find among the Corinthians on his next visit.

questions.question: What kinds of sins does Paul mention in 2 Corinthians 12:21 that some have committed and not repented of?
questions.correctAnswer: Uncleanness, fornication, and lasciviousness
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:21, Paul mentions uncleanness, fornication, and lasciviousness as sins committed without repentance.

questions.question: True or False: Paul says in 2 Corinthians 12:1 that it is expedient for him to glory.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:1 states it is not expedient for Paul to glory, indicating he does not find it appropriate to boast.

questions.question: True or False: Paul says in 2 Corinthians 12:13 that he was burdensome to the Corinthians.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul asks for forgiveness for any wrong but states in 2 Corinthians 12:13 that he was not burdensome to the Corinthians.

questions.question: True or False: Paul says in 2 Corinthians 12:11 that he is behind the very chiefest apostles in nothing.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:11, Paul claims he is in no way behind the chiefest apostles.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Corinthians 12:15: 'And I will very gladly spend and be ______ for you.'
questions.correctAnswer: spent
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:15 says Paul will gladly spend and be spent for the Corinthians.

medium.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of weakness and inadequacy. Based on 2 Corinthians 12, what biblical truth would you share about God's strength?
options: God's strength is made perfect in human weakness
Weakness shows that God has abandoned us
We must overcome weakness by our own effort
Weakness is a sign of lack of faith
questions.correctAnswer: God's strength is made perfect in human weakness
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:9 teaches that God's grace is sufficient and that His strength is made perfect in weakness, encouraging believers to rely on God's power rather than their own.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 12 instruct believers to view their own infirmities or trials?
options: As opportunities to boast in God's power
As reasons to withdraw from fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: As opportunities to boast in God's power
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 12:5 and 12:9-10 that he will glory in his infirmities so that the power of Christ may rest upon him, showing that trials can be occasions to display God's strength.

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for not boasting about himself, but rather about his weaknesses?
options: To prevent others from thinking too highly of him
Because he is ashamed of his faith
Because he has no spiritual gifts
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent others from thinking too highly of him
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:6-7, Paul explains that he refrains from boasting to avoid anyone thinking more highly of him than they should, and he mentions the thorn in the flesh to keep him humble.

questions.question: A believer feels burdened by persistent struggles. According to 2 Corinthians 12, what is a biblical response to ongoing hardship?
options: To pray persistently and trust God’s grace
To give up and isolate oneself
To ignore the problem and hope it goes away
To blame others for the hardship
questions.correctAnswer: To pray persistently and trust God’s grace
questions.explanation: Paul prayed three times for his thorn to be removed (12:8), but God’s response emphasized grace and strength in weakness (12:9), teaching perseverance in prayer and trust.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the 'thorn in the flesh' given to him?
options: A messenger of Satan to buffet him
questions.correctAnswer: A messenger of Satan to buffet him
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:7, Paul identifies the thorn as a 'messenger of Satan' sent to keep him humble and prevent pride from the abundance of revelations.

questions.question: What does Paul say about his apostleship compared to the 'very chiefest apostles'?
options: He is not behind them in anything
He is inferior to them in every way
He claims to be superior to them
questions.correctAnswer: He is not behind them in anything
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:11, Paul asserts that he is not inferior to the chief apostles, defending his ministry despite his hardships and weaknesses.

questions.question: Based on 2 Corinthians 12, how should parents approach their responsibility toward their children?
options: Parents should provide and not expect to be supported by children
Children should always provide for their parents first
Parents and children should be financially independent
questions.correctAnswer: Parents should provide and not expect to be supported by children
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:14, Paul teaches that children ought not to lay up for parents, but parents for children, highlighting parental responsibility.

questions.question: What does Paul say about his financial dealings with the Corinthian church?
options: He was not burdensome to them and did not seek to gain by them
He charged them high fees for his ministry
He demanded financial support as a right
He took advantage of them for profit
questions.correctAnswer: He was not burdensome to them and did not seek to gain by them
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:13 and 16-17, Paul emphasizes that he did not burden or gain from the Corinthians and acted with integrity and care.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 12, Paul was willing to spend and be spent for the sake of the believers, even if they loved him less.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:15 shows Paul's sacrificial love as he willingly spends and is spent for the Corinthians, even though the more he loves them, the less he is loved.

questions.question: True or False: Paul feared that upon his return to Corinth, he might find the believers living in harmony without any disputes.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:20, Paul expresses fear that he might find debates, envyings, wrath, and other conflicts among the believers, not harmony.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul says, 'Most gladly therefore will I rather glory in my _______, that the power of Christ may rest upon me.'
questions.correctAnswer: infirmities
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:9 states Paul’s willingness to glory in his infirmities so that Christ’s power may rest on him, highlighting humility and reliance on God.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 12, what is the purpose of the 'thorn in the flesh' given to Paul?
options: To keep him from being exalted above measure
To punish him for his sins
To prove his lack of faith
questions.correctAnswer: To keep him from being exalted above measure
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:7 explains that the thorn was given to prevent Paul from becoming proud due to the abundance of revelations he received.

questions.question: How does Paul describe his ministry signs among the Corinthians?
options: Wrought with patience, signs, wonders, and mighty deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Wrought with patience, signs, wonders, and mighty deeds
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:12 states that the signs of an apostle were shown with patience, signs, wonders, and mighty deeds among the believers.

questions.question: What does Paul hope to avoid when he comes again to the Corinthians, according to 2 Corinthians 12?
options: Finding them unrepentant in sin and disorder
questions.correctAnswer: Finding them unrepentant in sin and disorder
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:20-21, Paul fears finding sin, uncleanness, and unrepentant believers, which would cause him sorrow and humility.

questions.question: What is Paul's attitude towards glorying in himself, as expressed in 2 Corinthians 12?
options: He refrains from glorying in himself but boasts in infirmities
He boasts proudly about his achievements
He refuses to speak of himself at all
He only boasts about his visions
questions.correctAnswer: He refrains from glorying in himself but boasts in infirmities
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:5 explains Paul’s choice to glory not in himself but in his weaknesses to demonstrate Christ’s power.

hard.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Corinthians Chapter 12.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 12, Paul mentions a man caught up to the third heaven. What does the 'third heaven' most likely symbolize in the Jewish cosmological worldview?
options: The dwelling place of God and the highest spiritual realm
The earthly sky where birds fly
A metaphor for paradise on earth
questions.correctAnswer: The dwelling place of God and the highest spiritual realm
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Corinthians 12:2 refers to being caught up to the 'third heaven,' which in Jewish cosmology was understood as the highest heaven, the dwelling place of God, distinct from the atmospheric and stellar heavens.

questions.question: Paul speaks of hearing 'unspeakable words' in paradise. What literary device is used here to emphasize the ineffability of divine revelation?
questions.correctAnswer: Paradox
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:4 mentions 'unspeakable words,' highlighting a paradox because the words are heard but cannot be spoken, emphasizing the mysterious and sacred nature of the revelation.

questions.question: Paul refers to a 'thorn in the flesh' given to him. What is the likely purpose of this 'thorn' according to the text?
options: To keep him humble and prevent exaltation above measure
To punish him for his sins
To physically harm him as a sign of weakness
To separate him from the other apostles
questions.correctAnswer: To keep him humble and prevent exaltation above measure
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:7 explains that the thorn was given as a messenger of Satan to buffet Paul and prevent him from being exalted above measure due to the abundance of revelations.

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul's statement 'My grace is sufficient for thee: for my strength is made perfect in weakness' in the broader biblical theme of divine strength in human weakness?
options: It shows God's power is most evident when human ability fails
It suggests that weakness is a punishment from God
It implies that grace is only for the strong
It means that human strength is unnecessary for faith
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God's power is most evident when human ability fails
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:9, Paul's statement reflects the biblical theme where God's power is perfected in human weakness, teaching reliance on divine grace rather than personal strength.

questions.question: Paul says he will 'glory in my infirmities'. What New Testament theme does this reflect?
options: Avoidance of suffering at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering produces perseverance and character
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:5 and 12:9-10 indicate that Paul embraces infirmities as a means through which the power of Christ rests upon him, reflecting the theme that suffering contributes to spiritual growth.

questions.question: In verse 12, Paul mentions 'signs, and wonders, and mighty deeds'. Which Old Testament figure is associated with similar manifestations as a validation of divine authority?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: The signs, wonders, and mighty deeds parallel those performed by Moses in Exodus, which served to authenticate his role as God's chosen leader, similar to Paul's apostolic validation in 2 Corinthians 12:12.

questions.question: Paul appeals to the Corinthians that he has not been burdensome to them. How does this reflect Greco-Roman cultural expectations about patronage and leadership?
options: Leaders were expected to provide support without financial gain
Leaders should always be paid for their services
Patrons were obligated to exploit their clients
Financial burden was a sign of respect
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders were expected to provide support without financial gain
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:13-14, Paul highlights that he has not burdened the Corinthians, aligning with cultural ideals where a leader or patron was respected for generosity rather than seeking personal gain.

questions.question: What rhetorical strategy does Paul use in verse 15 when he says he will 'spend and be spent' for the Corinthians?
options: Simile to compare himself to others
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole to emphasize self-sacrifice
questions.explanation: Paul’s phrase in 2 Corinthians 12:15 uses hyperbole to stress his willingness to exhaust himself for the benefit of the Corinthians, highlighting his deep love and commitment.

questions.question: True or False: Paul admits in 2 Corinthians 12 that he might have acted craftily to ensure the Corinthians would not be burdened.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:16, Paul acknowledges using craftiness and guile to avoid burdening the Corinthians, showing a nuanced approach to leadership.

questions.question: Which theme in 2 Corinthians 12 connects to the Old Testament concept of a prophetic messenger being 'buffeted' or opposed?
options: The 'thorn in the flesh' as a form of divine testing
The call to kingship and conquest
The establishment of a physical temple
questions.correctAnswer: The 'thorn in the flesh' as a form of divine testing
questions.explanation: Paul’s 'thorn in the flesh' in 2 Corinthians 12:7 echoes Old Testament themes where prophets faced opposition and testing as part of their calling (e.g., Jeremiah's hardships).

questions.question: How does Paul’s concern in verse 20 about finding the Corinthians with 'debates, envyings, wraths' relate to the broader New Testament warnings about church unity?
options: It warns against divisions that disrupt the body of Christ
It suggests that conflict is unavoidable and acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: It warns against divisions that disrupt the body of Christ
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:20, Paul fears discord in the church, reflecting New Testament teachings (e.g., Philippians 2:2, Ephesians 4:3) urging believers to maintain unity and peace.

questions.question: Paul’s statement in 2 Corinthians 12:10, 'when I am weak, then am I strong,' is an example of what type of literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Paradox
questions.explanation: This statement in 2 Corinthians 12:10 is a paradox because it presents two seemingly contradictory ideas that reveal a deeper spiritual truth about strength through weakness.

questions.question: The phrase 'caught up into paradise' in verse 4 has intertextual connections with which Old Testament concept?
options: The Garden of Eden as a place of divine presence
Mount Sinai where God gave the Law
questions.correctAnswer: The Garden of Eden as a place of divine presence
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:4’s 'paradise' evokes the Edenic ideal from Genesis, symbolizing a place of intimate fellowship with God, aligning with the theme of heavenly ascent.

questions.question: Which Greek term best captures the meaning of 'reproaches' mentioned in verse 10, reflecting insults or shame endured for Christ?
questions.correctAnswer: ἀτιμία (atimía)
questions.explanation: The word 'reproaches' in 2 Corinthians 12:10 corresponds to ἀτιμία (atimía), meaning dishonor or shame, referring to insults suffered for Christ’s sake.

questions.question: Paul’s self-description as a 'fool in glorying' in verse 11 employs what rhetorical technique common in Pauline letters?
options: Irony to humble himself and contrast worldly wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Irony to humble himself and contrast worldly wisdom
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 12:11, Paul uses irony to refer to himself as a 'fool' in boasting, which serves to humble himself and critique worldly standards of wisdom.

theological.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Corinthians Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 12, what was Paul caught up to, which he describes as beyond earthly realms?
questions.correctAnswer: The third heaven
questions.explanation: Paul describes being caught up to the third heaven, a term indicating the highest heaven or divine realm (2 Corinthians 12:2). This aligns with other biblical references to heavens above the earthly realm (Genesis 1:1, Psalm 148:4, Isaiah 66:1, Revelation 4:1).

questions.question: What did Paul hear when he was caught up into paradise, according to 2 Corinthians 12?
options: The sound of a heavenly choir
questions.correctAnswer: Unspeakable words
questions.explanation: Paul states he heard unspeakable words which man is not permitted to utter (2 Corinthians 12:4). This reflects the ineffability of divine revelation (Exodus 33:20, Job 40:4, Isaiah 6:5, Revelation 10:4).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for not boasting about himself but rather in his infirmities?
options: So that the power of Christ may rest upon him
To gain sympathy from the church
Because he was commanded to do so by the apostles
questions.correctAnswer: So that the power of Christ may rest upon him
questions.explanation: Paul explains that boasting in infirmities is a way to display Christ’s power in human weakness (2 Corinthians 12:9-10). This theme is consistent with biblical teaching on God's strength perfected in weakness (Isaiah 40:29, Psalm 73:26, Matthew 11:28-30, James 4:6).

questions.question: What was the 'thorn in the flesh' given to Paul, and what purpose did it serve?
options: A messenger of Satan to buffet him, to prevent pride
A physical illness to test his faith
A financial burden to humble him
questions.correctAnswer: A messenger of Satan to buffet him, to prevent pride
questions.explanation: Paul describes the thorn as a messenger of Satan given to buffet him and keep him from becoming conceited due to the abundance of revelations (2 Corinthians 12:7). This reflects the biblical principle of God permitting trials to humble His servants (Job 1:12, 2 Corinthians 11:23-27, Hebrews 12:5-11, James 1:2-4).

questions.question: How many times did Paul beseech the Lord to remove the thorn in the flesh?
questions.correctAnswer: Three times
questions.explanation: Paul states that he prayed three times for the thorn to depart (2 Corinthians 12:8). This number often signifies completeness or divine perfection in Scripture (Exodus 34:28, Daniel 10:2-3, Luke 13:32, Acts 9:9).

questions.question: What was God’s response to Paul's request to remove the thorn?
options: My grace is sufficient for thee; for my strength is made perfect in weakness
Wait patiently and I will heal you
You must bear it for your sanctification
I will remove it in my time
questions.correctAnswer: My grace is sufficient for thee; for my strength is made perfect in weakness
questions.explanation: God replies that His grace is sufficient and His strength is perfected in human weakness (2 Corinthians 12:9). This aligns with biblical themes of God's sustaining grace (Psalm 46:1, Isaiah 40:29, 2 Corinthians 1:9, Hebrews 4:16).

questions.question: According to Paul in 2 Corinthians 12, when is he strong?
options: When he is in good health
questions.correctAnswer: When he is weak
questions.explanation: Paul paradoxically states that he is strong when he is weak, highlighting dependence on Christ’s power (2 Corinthians 12:10). This concept is consistent with biblical teachings on humility and strength through God (Psalm 73:26, Matthew 5:3, Philippians 4:13, James 4:6).

questions.question: What signs did Paul claim confirmed his apostleship among the Corinthians?
questions.correctAnswer: Signs, wonders, and mighty deeds
questions.explanation: Paul attested that signs, wonders, and mighty deeds accompanied his ministry to prove his apostleship (2 Corinthians 12:12). This aligns with New Testament criteria for authentic apostleship (Acts 2:43, Hebrews 2:4, Mark 16:17-18, John 14:12).

questions.question: Why does Paul say he was not burdensome to the Corinthian church?
options: Because he did not seek their material support
Because he avoided visiting them often
Because he sent other teachers instead
questions.correctAnswer: Because he did not seek their material support
questions.explanation: Paul explains that he did not burden the Corinthians financially (2 Corinthians 12:13), reflecting his desire to preach free of charge as an example (Acts 20:33-35, 1 Thessalonians 2:9, 1 Corinthians 9:15-18, Galatians 2:10).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for his willingness to spend and be spent for the Corinthians?
options: Because of his abundant love for them
Because he sought to gain status
Because he wanted to avoid other churches
questions.correctAnswer: Because of his abundant love for them
questions.explanation: Paul states he gladly spends and is spent for them out of abundant love, even though they may love him less (2 Corinthians 12:15). This reflects Christ's sacrificial love as a model (John 15:13, 2 Timothy 2:10, Romans 5:8, 1 John 3:16).

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 12, Paul expresses concern about what kinds of issues existing in the Corinthian church?
options: Debates, envyings, wraths, strifes, backbitings, whisperings, swellings, tumults
questions.correctAnswer: Debates, envyings, wraths, strifes, backbitings, whisperings, swellings, tumults
questions.explanation: Paul fears finding discord and sinful behaviors among them (2 Corinthians 12:20), which threaten church unity as warned elsewhere (James 3:14-16, Galatians 5:19-21, Philippians 2:2-4, 1 Corinthians 1:10).

questions.question: What does Paul fear he might do when he comes again to the Corinthians if they have not repented?
options: Be humbled among them and bewail those who have sinned
Ignore their sins and praise them
questions.correctAnswer: Be humbled among them and bewail those who have sinned
questions.explanation: Paul fears God will humble him among them and that he will mourn over many unrepentant sinners (2 Corinthians 12:21), echoing biblical calls for repentance and church discipline (1 Corinthians 5:1-5, Hebrews 12:6, Revelation 3:19, Luke 19:41-44).

questions.question: What does Paul say about boasting in 2 Corinthians 12?
options: He will glory in the Lord's revelations and in his infirmities
He refuses to boast at all
He boasts only about his visions
questions.correctAnswer: He will glory in the Lord's revelations and in his infirmities
questions.explanation: Paul chooses to glory in the revelations given by the Lord and especially in his weaknesses (2 Corinthians 12:1,5), reflecting humility and dependence on God’s grace (Psalm 34:18, Jeremiah 9:23-24, Philippians 3:3-8, Romans 5:3-5).

questions.question: Paul mentions being 'a fool in glorying' because of what reason?
options: Because he wanted to impress them
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Corinthians compelled him
questions.explanation: Paul states he became a fool in boasting because the Corinthians compelled him, indicating his reluctant defense of his apostleship (2 Corinthians 12:11). This reflects the biblical principle of humility and the need to answer critics (1 Corinthians 9:3, 2 Timothy 4:2, Acts 20:24, Galatians 1:10).

questions.question: What principle about family support does Paul mention when discussing his ministry to the Corinthians?
options: Children should not lay up for parents, but parents for children
Parents should always provide for children
Ministers should be financially supported by churches
questions.correctAnswer: Children should not lay up for parents, but parents for children
questions.explanation: Paul teaches that children ought not to save for their parents, but parents for their children (2 Corinthians 12:14), reflecting biblical principles on family responsibility (1 Timothy 5:8, Ephesians 6:4, Proverbs 13:22, Malachi 4:6).
